awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Present and Projected Future Forcings on Antarctic Peninsula Glaciers and Ice Shelves using the Weather Forecasting and Research (WRF) Model
awd_abstract_narration:
Hock/1543432

Over the last half century the Antarctic Peninsula has been among the most rapidly warming regions in the world. This has led to increased glacier melt, widespread glacier retreat, ice-shelf collapses, and glacier speed-ups. Many of these changes are driven by changing precipitation and increased melt due to warmer air temperatures. This project will use a combination of two models - a regional atmospheric model and a model of processes at the glacier surface - to simulate future changes in temperature and snowfall, and the resulting changes in glacier mass. The combination of models will be tested against the observational record (since 1979 when satellite observations became available), to verify that it can reproduce observed change, and then run to the year 2100. Results will provide better estimates of the impacts of future climate changes over the Antarctic Pensinsula and the expected glacier mass changes driven by the evolving climate. 

The project will use the large changes observed on the Peninsula to validate a model framework suitable for understanding the impact of these changes on the glaciers and ice shelves there, with the goal of developing optimally constrained future climate and surface mass change scenarios for the region. The framework will provide both a coherent picture of the impacts of past changes on the region?s ice cover, and also the best available constraints on forcings that will determine ice mass loss from this region going forward under a standard scenario.  The Weather Forecasting and Research (WRF) Model will be used over the domain of the Antarctic Peninsula and neighboring islands to quantify trends in spatio-temporal patterns of mass change with a focus on surface melt. The WRF model will be enhanced to account for the specific conditions of glacier surfaces, and the modified model will be used to simulate climate conditions and resulting surface mass budgets and melt over the period 1979-2100. Tying modeled past climate changes to the surface and satellite-based observational record will provide a foundation for interpreting projected future change. Results will be validated using available weather station observations, surface mass-balance data, and satellite-derived records of melt.  The activity will foster partnerships through collaboration with colleagues in Spain, Germany and The Netherlands and will support an early-career postdoctoral researcher and two graduate students, introduce undergraduate and high-school students to original research and provide training of students through inclusion of data and results in course curriculums.

por.por_cntn:
Over the last half century the Antarctic Peninsula has been among the most rapidly warming regions in the world leading, for example, to increased glacier melt, widespread glacier retreat, and ice-shelf break-up. Direct measurements of surface melt in Antarctica are rare, but remote sensing methods can be applied to assess climate change impacts on the ice sheet. We used passive microwave satellite observations to track the number of days throughout the year with surface melt in Antarctica with focus on the surrounding ice shelves. We used these data to determine the number of melt days per year between 1978 and 2020 using a method developed in this project. Results were compared to several other existing melt detection algorithms and also to results derived from Synthetic Aperture Radar measurements from the Sentinel-1 satellite, which has taken imagery of the Antarctic Peninsula every 1 to 3 days from 2016 on. Our passive microwave derived results indicate that our melt detection method works well; it has high accuracy and is the least biased to overcount or undercount melt compared to the other applied methods.

We then quantified the number of melt days and investigated any trends and patterns, and we also studied how they are connected to wider climate phenomena. From 1979-2020, the highest number of melt days occurred on ice shelves on the Antarctic Peninsula, with the Wilkins Ice Shelf averaging 89 melt days each year. Surprisingly, there are few linear trends in the number of melt days over the time period. Years of especially high melt can be split into two distinct categories: those with high melt days in Dronning Maud Land and Wilkes Land in East Antarctica, and those with high melt melt days in the Antarctic Peninsula and the Bellingshausen Sea sector of West Antarctica. The former pattern correlates with a climate index called Southern Annular Mode. This climate index serves as a proxy for the southward or northward migration of the Southern Westerly Winds. High melt days in the Antarctic Peninsula are not related to strong or consistent patterns of melt days elsewhere across the continent, implying that the causes of high melt in the Antarctic Peninsula do not have as great an effect elsewhere on the continent. Meanwhile, high melt days in Dronning Maud Land are related to slightly lower melt in the Antarctic Peninsula. Finally, we found that areas experiencing extended melt for the first time in years tend to show large decreases in subsequent winter microwave emissions due to structural changes in the snow layers, and this effect can be visible in the passive microwave record. We use this finding to identify the impact of high melt events, particularly over the austral summers of 1991/92 and 2015/16 on the Ross Ice Shelf.
